awd_titl_txt: DIMENSIONS: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Biodiversity Gradients in Obligate Symbiotic Organisms: A Case Study in Lichens in a Global Diversity Hotspot
awd_abstract_narration:
Obligate symbioses are relationships between two or more species that depend entirely on each other for growth and survival. Such symbioses characterize some of the most common and ecologically important relationships on Earth, ranging from human gut bacteria and diseases to corals and specialized plant-pollinator relationships. Yet, many of these obligate symbioses are imperiled by unprecedented rates of environmental change and permanent biodiversity losses. Compared to single branches on the tree of life such as birds, flowering plants, or mammals, much less is known about the factors that facilitate or limit the distributions of the obligate symbioses that abound in nature. Moreover, research on biodiversity distributions has focused largely on abiotic factors (e.g., temperature, precipitation, elevation) rather than on biotic factors (i.e., interactions with other organisms) that influence geographical distributions. This project will uncover the factors that impact diversity and distributions of obligate symbiotic lichens as a model system.  The geographic focus is the southern Appalachian Mountains of the southeastern U.S. -- a global lichen diversity hotspot and unique natural laboratory. In addition, this project will develop human capital and infrastructure in U.S. lichenology through student training, collaborations, and outreach to resource managers and the public.  It will establish a publicly available, high quality dataset and improve physical and digital resources that advance lichen conservation for a global biodiversity hotspot.

Despite generations of research on, and proposed theories for factors that generate and maintain biodiversity, consensus is lacking. Biotic factors have long been proposed as drivers, but they are rarely studied due to the difficulty of assessing the multitude of possible interactions. Because of the inherent biotic interaction between obligate symbionts, lichens offer a unique opportunity to explore both biotic and abiotic drivers of biodiversity across multiple dimensions. This project will utilize both field and genomic inventories of lichens in a global biodiversity hotspot. The research will generate and synthesize data from multiple symbiotic biodiversity dimensions initiated from a single information source: a unique museum voucher. Across local, regional, and landscape scales, the project will record site-specific metrics for phylogenetic (including taxonomic) and functional diversity together with site-specific metrics for a mostly unexplored genetic dimension, potential of diversity, that quantifies the availability of compatible symbiont propagules in the environment. Analysis of these metrics in light of biotic and abiotic variables enables assessment of factors that impact the dimensions of biodiversity. These analyses will also permit understanding of interactions among dimensions, for example, whether all are positively correlated and predicted by the same sets of variables, or in what contexts other types of correlations exist. This project is designed to yield two major conceptual advances in ecology and evolutionary biology. First, it will reveal new, emergent properties of biodiversity gradients in symbiotic organisms. Second, deconstructing constraints on individual partners of the symbiosis and quantifying feedbacks between and among them will make possible a full analysis, including biotic constraints, of the factors that impact diversity and distribution of the symbiotic organism as a whole.

por.por_cntn:
Perspectives on plants, fungi and other forms of life were historically focused on single species or individuals. However, we have come to increasingly recognize that species and individuals do not exist in isolation: Life on Earth is made up of communities driven by dynamic interactions. These interactions can be with among living things (i.e., biotic, like plant-pollinator relationships) or between living things and the environment (i.e., with abiotic factors, like the relationship between plant photosynthesis and sunlight). Documenting and describing these interactions is key to unraveling the patterns and processes at play in the natural world. Understanding these interactions, patterns and processes is also a crucial part of safeguarding the planet for future generations.

This project studied lichens in the Southern Appalachian Mountains of eastern North America for use as a model framework to understand what interactions facilitate or limit the occurrences of obligate symbioses in nature. Obligate symbioses are biotic interactions wherein two or more organisms rely on each other for their collective survival. Lichens are iconic obligate symbioses formed between fungi and photosynthesizing organisms (algae and/or cyanobacteria). The Southern Appalachian Mountains are a global hotspot of ecological and biological diversity. With more than a thousand lichen species distributed across an array of ecosystems, the region is an ideal natural laboratory.

The project team assembled a series of large-scale datasets for Southern Appalachian lichens and their associated ecosystems. Over five years of intensive fieldwork throughout the Southern Appalachian Mountains, the team established 206 one-hectare plots distributed across protected areas in Alabama, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee. In each plot, an intensive lichen inventory was completed, habitat quality and other site characteristics/ecological metrics quantified and archival photographs. Environment DNA (e-DNA) samples were also taken from micro-plots on trees and rocks, also with archival photographs. The plots contained 872 species including more than a dozen that were described as new to science during the project. More than 19,936 new natural history collections were made. These were curated and digitized at NYBG, with digital disseminated through biodiversity data platforms. These vouchers, together with plot level ecological and spatial data were used to build a prototype Extended Specimen Network using the C.V. Starr Virtual Herbarium at NYBG. In addition to natural history collections, a trait matrix as assembled for all 872 species, more than 3400 e-DNA samples were collected for and 890 lichen specimens were subsampled for whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing.

Studies by the team demonstrated that lichen biodiversity gradients across morphological and functional groups are strongly driven by habitat quality. The team developed new bioinformatic pipelines to characterize and compare the lichen symbionts present in the environment to those found growing within a given plot, resulting a publication on advances in microbial ecology. Newly assembled lichen mitochondrial genomes served as the basis for new insights on genomic streamlining, intron evolution and organellar genome structure for these organisms. Collaboration with functional ecologists led to important contributions on carbon capture mechanisms in lichen associated algae and cyanobacteria as drivers of distributions and communities.

Importantly all aspects of the project (i.e., field and laboratory studies, dataset compilation, data dissemination, building of online resources and preparation of publications) were carried out by a diverse cohort that included professional scientists, graduate and undergraduate students, and in many cases community scientists. Extensive outreach was carried out during the project, including development of a new course on symbioses, teaching of introductory lichen courses both in New York City and Appalachia, week-long identification workshops in Appalachia, and public presentations to stakeholder groups.

The knowledge, resources and infrastructure built by this project provide a strong foundation for future studies of obligate symbiont biodiversity gradients while also informing conservation of critically threatened organisms and ecosystems in the globally unique American biodiversity hotspot.
